Larry, rules choice depends on which era you wish to wargame and may depend=
 on what your available opponents will play.  First mention should go to Ki=
ller Katanas, a thoughtfully crafted set of rules specific to the popular 1=
550-1650 period of internal conflict in Japan (though an expansion booklet =
covers the interesting Imjin War in Korea). It may be difficult to find opp=
onents who play the rules,  but it is in any case worth buying as a backgro=
und resource.  

Japanese armies have been popular under rules sets with a =
broad historical span due to both historical interest and success on the ta=
ble.  DBA was mentioned - it has 12 stands of troops per side (requiring ro=
ughly 40 miniatures), is quick and can be fun.  Many people prefer larger b=
attles (which might be a hundred, or two hundred or more, miniatures).  I p=
layed Samurai under DBA's large-scale successor DBM years ago (though not u=
nder its recent successor DBMM), and more recently under the widely-used Fi=
eld of Glory rules (acronym FOG) that is my current preference for general =
period ancient/medieval rules (a forthcoming version of FOG covering 1500 w=
ill be my choice for that overall period).  All these general rules contemp=
late both historical and ahistorical matches between armies (what if Hideyo=
shi had fought the Spanish or Dutch?), which can be an advantage, but are f=
ocused on the tactical interactions between the opponents in a large battle=
 and lack the nuances and characterization seen in period-specific rules (d=
ueling, for example, or the interplay of special formations). 

These sets =
and many others share or support a fairly standard scheme of base sizes and=
 numbers of miniatures per base, which allows playing different rules sets =
with the same miniatures.  Base sizes vary with the scale of the miniatures=
, 15mm and 25/28mm being the most common, with base widths of 40mm and 60mm=
 respectively.  Taking this into account will allow flexibility in playing =
different rules sets.  

Warhammer Ancient Battles (acronym WAB) is a fairl=
y widespread rules set that is played with 28mm miniatures and has army lis=
ts with army-specific chrome and special units (such as Ninjas).  It puts a=
ttention on individual unit special attributes and abilities rather than fo=
cusing on tactical interactions of troop types. It has individual miniature=
 bases which are often moved on WAB trays, but suitably sized and matched m=
agnetic/steel bases can be used to play other rules sets with the same mini=
atures.  

There are other sets of rules out there, including homebrew rule=
s or adaptations of existing rules sets.  I'd suggest seeing what people ar=
e playing in your vicinity.

I hope this is helpful!

Mike
